Mitt Romney is not running for President; he's running against Barack Obama. His own proposals and policies are hardly a counterweight to his attacks on the President's actions and policies he is careful never to describe. We know he put the dog on top of the car. (Thank you, Gail!) And that old saw in itself is a measure of exactly how old and tired Romney's vagaries have become. Will he engage an emerging Africa as a growing market of raw materials and an importer of green and high tech products? How will he expand US imports to China? What's his plan to fight terrorism? Where does he stand on drone attacks? Will he shift refugee food aid to the safer, cost effective, locally producive card payments the UN and others advocate? Or will he protect corporate food interests who benefit from the higher costs of food transfers? What's his uban and educational policies? His alternative to the Affordable Care Act?

Given his weighty and lengthy desire to be President, he is light as a feather on details. He sees the government as his next big take over, takedown, outsource, reap wealth project. He has had ample time to form a plan. Instead, he is seeking to win by by fear and default.

If his own party doesn't trust him, and had him behind Herman Cain and Rick Perry--whose command of the knowledge needed for the office was predicated on advisors and do-overs--why should America trust a man whose principal appeal is his self-described use of the word, "failed?"

If those in the anti-Romney camp can overlook the many flip-flops, the disatrous moral vices (personal and political) of Newt Gingrich, their now choice to correct the wrongs in Washington (fundamentaly insane)...then certainly a few nuanced reversals by Mitt Romney (radioactive-free) can be also overlooked.

That is if Gingrich and Romney were on a level playing field.

Alex,
I appreciate yr interest in Obama's platform in the last campaign. Obama said he would re-engage education with state competitive incentives--and he has. He specifically said he would go after Bin Laden--and he did. He said he would reform Health care--and he did. He said he would end DADT--and he did.

The Pulitzer winner PolitiFact site keeps close tabs on the more than 500 commitments Obama made during the campaign, and rates 207 promises met (including compromises), and 245 either stalled or in the works. (In comparison, Republicans have kept 10 of 57 promises made at mid-term.)

Obama's plans and platform were long on details, and he has implemented as promised.

I might note that popular sentiment is also clearly troubled by Romney's vagaries, as are his opponents within the GOP. It certainly contributes to him, after 6 years, never arising above 25% in GOP polls.

America has it's problems, but that shouldn't distract attention from Russia's.  It's not a valid excuse.  Minding your own business is fine, except when you're not speaking out about abuses. Black Holes are nice but you wouldn't want to live near one.

Why not just enjoy being part of this great cosmic experiment called Earth with all its majesty and silliness? Fortunately we find ourselves on exclusive real estate in just the right proximity to the sun. And we have water, what else can time travelers ask for? Now if we can only learn how to share the bounty.

Centuries old understanding placed humanity at the creation of and at the service for a humanoid "God" somewhere above us in the heavens. Now, science, in particular astronomy and cosmology has revealed extreme puzzles as presented by the positing of black holes, which were never ever included in traditional religious explanations of the "world" or universe.
Isn't it time for us to escape from the self-satisfying arrogant position that we are the center of attraction in all of existence? Light years distant from any realistic communication possibilities and faced with immense forces of an accelerating expansive universe, dark matter and dark energy and impossibly immense black holes, isn't it likely that we are mere miniscule ants, helpless in the face of overwhelming indifferent forces?

I stopped at this response as I too couldn't wrap my mind around the idea of  "336 million light years away" while wondering what is happening there today in real time. I am still feeling astonished over having a few years ago watched an all night long meteor shower, a light show where drops of comet slush had been falling over 200 years before reaching earth's atmosphere to create a "falling stars" spectacle that will happen periodically many times in the future but not again in my lifetime.

336 million years is small on a galactic timescale.  Our own sun is about 4.5 Billion years old, and the Milky Way galaxy is about 13,700 Billion years old, and yet the black hole at the center of the galaxy hasn't gotten very far in devouring the galaxy's matter, and will likely never get the chance to devour the whole galaxy, because much of the galaxy's matter is too far away to fall into it.
Oops, clerical error.  The galaxy is about 13.7 Billion years old, not 13,700.

A few commenters have remarked on the substance abuse and attributed it to deadening the pain from injury or identified it as the primary cause of death, saying that hockey did not kill him but addiction did.

I agree he probably did use drugs and alcohol, in part, to deaden his injury pain. And, probably, to deal with the mental anguish of twisting what some of the video and article respondents said was a gentle personality into one that could, on demand, produce a desire to fight.

Nevertheless, a substance abuse problem is a disease in its own right and can only be addressed by acknowledging its existence and seeking help and ongoing reinforcement for recovery, for exanple through twelve-step programs.

The NYT has produced a provocative series that raises so many issues--the violence of hockey as played in the NHL, the development of hockey players and hockey enforcers, the needsof a child who may have had a learning disability and certainly suffered from a perception of not fitting in because of the family's frequent moves for his father's job, a professional sports organization that acts as an enabler for addictions by turning a blind eye to even its own doctors' prescribing patterns. Not to mention the pursuit of the amighty dollar by all concerned, including the league and the players themselves. One also empathizes with his family while feeling incredulity that his brother remains a hockey enforcer!

A very sad commentary on human nature and sports..

The problem, ultimately, is that all forms of violence simply cannot be rooted out of the sport. Sorry to be tautological, but unfortunately, sports are a reflection of large scale social trends, so we can either deal pragmatically with real world problems, such as violence in a sport, by facing the harsh realities of the sport's given makeup, or we can run a series of sensationalized articles, stir up a bunch of faux-nonsense public opinion, and then go back to our daily lives. I repeat - the best way to combat the issue of CTE in this sport is rule changes regarding blows to the head in the form of cheap shots and stick-work. If you remove fighting from the game, both of those categories of real, dangerous nonsense will increase. If your goal is to remove all violence from the game, then end hockey - it can't be done.

This is a fantastic series. One of the best things I've read in a long time. Kudos to Mr. Branch for his work. I have seen countless hockey fights on the evening news sports highlights and always dismissed them as silliness because the players just appeared to be taking wild, roundhouse swings at one another. I never realized the seriousness of the injuries they were inflicting until now.

The sad part is that even knowing the dangers of injury or addiction to pain killers, there are plenty of young players who would still choose to be "enforcers" just for the chance to play in the NHL (Aaron is the perfect example). In this respect they differ little from the retired football players with brain injuries who say they would still have chosen to play in the NFL even knowing that they would suffer disability in later life. The lure of money and fame is just too great. The individual players are not going to stop. It is up to the leagues and players' unions to take action to protect the players, and up to the fans of these sports to demand that they do so.

Thank you for sharing such an important story from so many different points of view. Growing up in a hockey family, I was able to see the many positive effects of the sport first-hand. However, I also saw the negative effects, as my brother suffered multiple concussions on the ice. Thinking back on my brother's headaches and other symptoms, coupled with watching the videos of the blows suffered by Boogaard during his countless fights, makes you wonder what is more important- a player's health or the tradition of the sport?

Add the easy, almost mandatory, access to the drugs. Wow.
